tossups.question: A group in this country was once subjected to forced conversion under the “Orphans’ Decree,” and suffered the year-long Mawza Exile in 1679. The “lower” text of a manuscript from this country was the first non-Uthmanic Qur’an text to be found when it was discovered in 1972. A group now found mainly in this country refused to recognize Muhammad al-Baqir and are thus sometimes called “Fivers.” A movement in this country has adopted the memorable slogan “God is the Greatest, Death to America, Death to Israel, Curse on the Jews, Victory to Islam.” The (*) targum continues to be used in the liturgy by Mizrahis from this country. This country’s once-large Jewish population was evacuated in Operation Magic Carpet. For 10 points, name this country whose Zaydi minority has formed the Houthi insurgency.
tossups.answer: Republic of Yemen [or al-Jumhūrīyah al-Yamanīyah] <Religion>

tossups.question: The bacterial enzyme SpnF in Saccharo·polyspora spinosa catalyzes a reaction of this general class. In the bacterial biosynthesis of the pyrrole ring of cobalamin, the conversion of precorrin-8x to hydrogeno·byrinate is a reaction of this general type. An example of one of these reactions occurs in the shikimic acid pathway in the production of prephenic acid, catalyzed by chorismate mutase. (*) Selenium dioxide is used in a reaction of this general type to form allylic alcohols. It’s not hydroxylation, but two separate examples of this class of reactions occur in the conversion of 7-de·hydro·cholesterol to vitamin D3 in the skin, both allowed under UV catalysis. Thermally allowed 4-electron examples of this class of reactions must either have a con·rotatory mechanism or involve an antara·facial migration. For 10 points, name this class of reactions governed by the Woodward–Hoffman rules.
tossups.answer: pericyclic reactions [anti-prompt on Diels–Alder, cycloaddition, sigmatropic rearrangement, Claisen rearrangement, or electrocyclization] <Science - Chemistry>

tossups.question: This character restores the sanity of knights imprisoned in Dragontina’s garden in order to take them to relieve the siege of Albracca. This character is carried offshore into a raging sea off the coast of northern France after a malevolent hermit sends a demon to possess this character’s horse. This character infiltrates the palace of Atlantes, where knights are beguiled by images of what they most desire, in order to be escorted home by Sacripante. Throughout the poem, this character uses the (*) “ring of reason” in order to pierce illusions and turn invisible. After this daughter of King Galaphron tends the wounded soldier Medoro, she falls in love with him—the sight of their names carved on trees leads another character to erupt into jealous anger. Her beauty causes knights like Ruggiero and Rinaldo to go mad with lust. For 10 points, name this princess of Cathay who flees from amorous men pursuing her throughout Orlando Furioso.
tossups.answer: Angelica <Literature - European>

tossups.question: Christopher Cappozolla argues that this policy worked in tandem with “coercive volunteerism” to remake masculinity and create the “modern citizen.” An uprising against this policy was noted for its striking racial diversity and greatly reduced leftist influence in the Great Plains region; that insurrection was named for the food that dissidents would eat while marching through Oklahoma. The iconic image of this policy was a ridiculous-looking Newton Baker wearing a sleep mask and groping blindly around a (*) bowl. The law establishing this policy was upheld by the Supreme Court in Arver v. US, which cited Emer de Vattel’s Law of Nations. A group created by this policy was defended by black lawyer Turner Bell after killing several Houston policemen in a race riot. A portion of the larger group created by this policy was sent to Arkhangelsk to rescue the Czech Legion in the Polar Bear Expedition. Emma Goldman was deported for opposing—for 10 points—what policy that mobilized Doughboys for the American Expeditionary Force in 1917?
tossups.answer: WWI conscription [or the Selective Service Act of 1917; or the WWI draft; prompt on partial answer; prompt on American entry into World War I or similar answers] <History - American>

tossups.question: This thinker noted that “it is difficult to maintain a philosophical discourse against light” in an essay that compares Hegel’s praise of sight with another thinker’s praise of hearing. The last two paragraphs of that essay by this thinker begin with the questions “are we Greeks?” and “are we Jews?” This 20th-century philosopher claimed that an earlier thinker installed “menace at the very heart of the intelligible” by proposing the (*) “evil demon” thought experiment. Another thinker responded to that essay by this man in “My Body, This Paper, This Fire.” In early essays, this man argued that face-to-face interaction is overvalued by Levinas and attacked Foucault’s Madness and Civilization. Those essays by this philosopher are “Violence and Metaphysics” and “Cogito and the History of Madness.” For 10 points, name this philosopher whose book Writing and Difference introduced his method of “deconstruction.”
tossups.answer: Jacques Derrida <Philosophy>

tossups.question: Eighteen works by this composer were published alongside contributions by friends like Elisabeth Cruciger in an Enchiridion conceived as a follow-up to this man’s “Eight-song Book.” Under the influence of the “Tenor-song” genre, this composer used the “A-A-B” Bar form for many of his tunes. In an 1834 review, Robert Schumann contrasted adaptations of this man’s music by Felix Mendelssohn and Giacomo Meyerbeer. A tune by this composer begins with three repeated Cs, followed by the shorter notes “G-A-B, C-B-A, G.” This man justified his vernacular adaptations of (*) Gregorian chants by supposedly asking “Why must the Devil have all the good tunes?” This composer’s “A Mighty Fortress Is Our God” was the basis for the last movement of Mendelssohn’s Symphony No. 5. For 10 points, name this German who advocated the use of instruments and polyphony in church, unlike his rival John Calvin.
tossups.answer: Martin Luther (Mendelssohn’s fifth is the “Reformation” Symphony.) <Arts - Auditory>

tossups.question: A planet consisting of these people is disturbed by the arrival of Russian astronauts in the short story “When it Changed.” Aliens attack Earth by releasing a virus that incites humans to murder these people in the short story “The Screwfly Solution.” Dr. Lorimer tries to prevent his fellow crew members Bud and Dave from conquering a planet populated by these people in James Tiptree Jr.’s novella Houston, Houston, Do You Read? It’s the first word in the title of a novel by (*) Marge Piercy in which one of these people telepathically visits the future utopian community of Mattapoisett; that novel is named for a person of this type On the Edge of Time. These people develop the ability to shoot electricity from their fingertips in Naomi Alderman’s novel The Power. For 10 points, name this general group of people whose rights are sharply curtailed under the Republic of Gilead in Margaret Atwood’s The Handmaid’s Tale.
tossups.answer: women [or woman; or Woman on the Edge of Time before mentioned; accept clear equivalents] <Literature - American>

tossups.question: This man’s affinity for his Czech intelligence contacts, who nicknamed him “Secretary,” led him to start wearing the zmijovka [zmee-YOHF-kah] cap, which is often mistaken for a traditional regional garment but in fact was popularized by this man. This leader’s forces split their time between insurgent attacks and setting up local agricultural infrastructure, reflecting his background in agronomy. This leader began an armed campaign after a dockworker strike he organized resulted in the (*) Pidjiguiti [pee-jee-ghee-tee] Massacre. This man’s activity outside his own country included delivering the “Weapon of Theory” speech at the 1966 Tricontinental Conference in Cuba and joining with Agostino Neto to co-found the MPLA in Angola. This man’s brother Luis instituted a repressive regime after he was assassinated, perhaps by Marcelo Caetano’s agents or by his former neighbor and ally, Ahmed Sékou Touré. For 10 points, name this leader of independence movements in Cape Verde and Guinea-Bissau.
tossups.answer: Amílcar (Lopes da Costa) Cabral [or Abel Djassi] <History - Other/World>

tossups.question: SUN-domain proteins in this fibrillar structure interact with KASH-domain proteins, which interact with actin. A protein in this structure must be farnesyl·ated and then de·farnesyl·ated, and hereditary failure to de·farnesyl·ate the pro·protein leads to a multisystem connective tissue disorder. Mutations in proteins localizing in this non-sarco·lemma structure can cause muscular dystrophy characterized by teenage-onset dilated cardio·myopathy with conduction defect and humero·peroneal weakness; that disease is (*) Emery–Dreifuss muscular dystrophy. Proteins localizing to this structure are phosphorylated by the cyclin-B/CDK1 complex—or MPF—at the end of G2 phase, which leads to its degradation. Condensed chromatin is tightly associated with this structure, as active transcription mostly occurs in the nuclear interior. For 10 points, name this structure localizing to the inner face of the nuclear envelope.
tossups.answer: nuclear lamina [prompt on nuclear envelope or even nucleus before they are read] <Science - Biology>

tossups.question: The speaker of one poem describes sitting in the “sunset shade” at this location, “nursing leg- and arch-cramps, my cowardly, / foolhardy heart.” A track off the album Tenderness Junction recorded live at this location includes the repeated chant “Out, Demons, Out!” The central figure of one novel imagines that the air at this location has been “injected with Novocain” before being arrested, getting into a staring contest with a neo-Nazi, and being moved to an Occoquan workhouse. Abbie (*) Hoffman and Jerry Rubin were among those who attempted to “exorcise” this building by levitating it during a protest organized by “the Mobe.” The photograph Flower Power shows a young man placing a carnation into the gun barrel of a soldier defending this building. Norman Mailer’s The Armies of the Night is an account of a 1967 march on—for 10 points—what building in Arlington, Virginia that serves as the headquarters for the Department of Defense?
tossups.answer: The Pentagon (The poem is Robert Lowell’s “The March 2.”) <Mythology and Other>

tossups.question: A series with this first title word uses transparencies to overlay text onto gouaches, and is subtitled “a singspiel.” Before being sent to Auschwitz at the age of 26, Charlotte Salomon painted a series of 769 works titled [This noun]? Or Theater? In an entry from a series with this last title word, a man holds a bloodstained hand to his heart while a faceless woman in white walks away to the right. That series with this last title word debuted at the Berlin (*) Secession ten years after its artist’s work had prompted the actual secession. This is the last title word of a series in which a woman’s blood-red hair drapes over a man she kisses on the neck. In another painting from that series with this last title word, a nude, red-haloed woman holds her right arm behind her head and her left arm at the small of her back. Madonna, Vampire, and Death in the Sickroom are part of a Frieze by Edvard Munch titled after—for 10 points—what concept?
tossups.answer: life [accept Life? Or Theater?: A Singspiel or Leben? oder Theater?: Ein Singespiel; accept Frieze of Life or Livsfrisen] (The first Munch painting is Separation.) <Arts - Visual>

tossups.question: One holder of this position, Henry Picard, used his reputation as a winemaker to entice John the Good, David II of Scotland, and others to attend the Feast of the 5 Kings. The first holder of this office presided over a large fire that incinerated thousands of people who had taken up residence on a newly-constructed bridge. A four-time holder of this position left a huge fortune for public use in his will, for which he was memorialized as a popular stage character who had numerous adventures with his (*) cat; that man was Dick Whittington. Ralph de Standish may have struck the blow often credited to a fishmonger named William Walworth who was serving in this post when he personally killed Wat Tyler. Thomas Bloodworth, a holder of this office, reportedly suggested that “a woman might piss it out” when he declined to respond to a fire on September 2, 1666. For 10 points, name this now chiefly ceremonial office in the UK’s capital city, not to be confused with an executive position currently held by Sadiq Khan.
tossups.answer: Lord Mayor of London [accept just Mayor of London until “Sadiq Khan”; do not accept or promptt on “Mayor of Greater London”] (“Mayor” and “Lord Mayor” are now different offices, but “Lord Mayor of London” used to be called just “Mayor” with great frequency.) <History - Euro>

tossups.question: Before having sex, a man in a novel by this author insists to the Lord that “this is not lust or lewdness, but to make a child to serve you.” Another novel by this author centers on a telegraph operator who is only “good at communicating and at loving Lucha” named Júbilo Chi. This author of Swift as Desire also wrote a novel centering on the romance between Rodrigo Sanchez and the astrologist Azucena Martinez titled The Law of Love. The funeral of a woman who dies “sighing out her last (*) flatulent breath” is attended by few guests due to the smell in a novel by this author that features the Native American grandmother Morning Light. This author wrote a novel that begins by urging the reader to place an onion on their head to keep from crying, and whose chapters each feature a different recipe. For 10 points, name this Mexican author who created Tita de la Garza in her novel Like Water for Chocolate.
tossups.answer: Laura Esquivel <Literature - Other/World>

tossups.question: The intuitions involved in this job were analyzed in a 2009 book by Karen Pearlman that draws on her experience dancing for Bill T. Jones. Man With a Movie Camera includes many shots of Elizaveta Svilova performing this job. Because this job was considered similar to sewing, women like Anne Bauchens and Margaret Booth were traditionally hired to perform it. During the 1970s, Americans began using (*) flatbed machines like the Steenbeck to perform this job. The “Rule of Six” is a set of guidelines for performing this job created by Walter Murch. Thelma Schoonmaker and Marcia Lucas performed this job for several films by Martin Scorsese. Adherents of this “invisible” art’s “continuity” style frequently use the “shot reverse shot” paradigm. For 10 points, name this part of post-production in which raw footage is assembled into a finished film.
tossups.answer: film editing [or film cutting; prompt on post-production or filmmaking] <Arts - Audiovisual, Other>

tossups.question: The essay that introduced this two-word concept argues that it is encouraged by a sense of “fictive kinship” that prioritizes “collectivity” over individualism. A paper by Ainsworth-Darnell and Downey used data from the NELS to argue that material conditions better explain a certain phenomenon than does this concept. Roland Fryer used a database of friendship networks to argue that this two-word concept becomes more salient in (*) schools with more interethnic contact. This concept was framed by one of its formulators as a manifestation of a certain group’s “oppositional culture” in a book about students in an affluent suburb, some of whom feel pressured not to enroll in honors classes. In order to explain the racial achievement gap, Signithia Fordham and John Ogbu described the “burden” of—for 10 points—what controversial two-word concept referring to the idea that educational success is a betrayal of black culture?
tossups.answer: acting white [prompt on oppositional culture until read] <Social Science>

tossups.question: These inputs determine the “activity factor” alpha that multiples “C V-squared” when computing dynamic power dissipation by a CMOS circuit. This input is encoded into a datastream in the 8b/10b and 64b/66b standards. In Passive Optical Networks, “burst mode” transmission is used to “recover” this input. Fractal H-trees are often used to distribute these signals after they pass through a phase-locked loop. This input is integrated into a signal by (*) Manchester coding. Each of the bits in a shift register is edge-triggered by one of these inputs. Unlike a latch, a flip-flop must have one of these inputs. The frequency of one of these inputs is dynamically adjusted in CPU throttling. A CPU’s gigahertz rating indicates the frequency of—for 10 points—what signal used to create synchronous circuits?
tossups.answer: clock signals [or timing signals; or time signals; accept clock recovery; prompt on frequency by asking “The frequency of which input?”] <Science - Other>

tossups.question: This city was an early nexus of European astronomy after al-Zarqali’s astronomical calculations were modified to center on this city in its set of namesake “Tables.” Gerard of Cremona oversaw this city’s namesake “school” of translation, which adapted numerous Arabic texts. Reccared converted from Arianism after a synod held in this city, which saw several of its innumerable church councils hosted by Isidore of Seville, part of the reason its archbishop is still the Primate of Hispania. Eleonora (*) of this city helped run Florence with her husband, Cosimo I de’ Medici. The Spanish Nationalist newspaper was named for this city’s Alcázar, which withstood a Republican siege. This city was the power base of Alfonso the Wise, who made it a hub of learning in Castile. The alloy produced in this city led it to rival Damascus as a major center of steel production. For 10 points, name this city in northern Spain, whose landscape was painted by its most famous resident, El Greco.
tossups.answer: Toledo <History - Mediterranean+>

tossups.question: In a novel by an author with this first name, the protagonist is proposed to by Mr. Osmond at a Masonic Ladies’ Night and befriends the aspiring author Ludo Myers. The title character of another novel by an author with this first name moves to Kent to escape from Constantine Ormeau and Iseult Smith. This first name is shared by the author of Mrs. Palfrey at the Claremont and an author whose final novel’s title character falls in love with Henry Dancey. In a novel by an author with this first name, Harrison suspects that Robert (*) Kelway, the lover of Stella Rodney, is a Nazi spy. Eva Trout is the final novel of an author with this first name who also wrote a novel centering on the orphan Portia Quayne. The Heat of the Day and The Death of the Heart were written by an author with—for 10 points—what first name shared by female British novelists surnamed Taylor and Bowen?
tossups.answer: Elizabeth [accept Elizabeth Taylor; accept Elizabeth Bowen] (Not the actress.) <Literature - British>

tossups.question: Note to players: The answer to this question is a large global region, like “The Middle East,” and not like “the Scottish Highlands” A book written about individuals in this region opens by explaining that even a small wave will drown a man standing up to his nose in water. That work argues that risk-aversion driven by hardship leads individuals in this region to prefer local patron-client exploitation to the free market, and was attacked by Samuel Popkin. The Moral Economy of the Peasant was written about this region by a thinker who argued that its upland inhabitants strategically construct their societies to resist state control in The Art of Not Being Governed. Tactics like “foot-dragging” are discussed in a book primarily about this region, (*) Weapons of the Weak, whose author also examined an impenetrable massif in this region called “Zomia.” For 10 points, name this region that is the primary focus of James C. Scott, whose Seeing Like a State includes a reflection on French colonial policies in its countries of Laos and Vietnam.
tossups.answer: Southeast Asia [accept Highland Southeast Asia or other similar answers; prompt on Asia but do not accept “East Asia”; anti-prompt on Zomia or Vietnam] <Modern World>

tossups.question: The Weitzenbock identity states that two different definitions of this form in differential geometry differ only by a zero-order linear operator. If the vorticity is everywhere zero, the Navier–Stokes equation can be reformulated into a much simpler equation involving this operator. This operator admits a generalization on Riemannian manifolds computed by taking the trace of the Hessian. The proof of Earnshaw’s theorem begins by applying this operator to the (*) energy of a magnetic dipole, which returns zero. This operator acting on “one over the polar coordinate r” is equal to “4 pi times the 3D delta function.” If this operator applied to a function is zero, the function’s value at a point equals the average of values on a sphere surrounding the point. The kinetic energy term of the 3D quantum Hamiltonian is equal to “negative h-bar-squared over 2m times this operator.” For 10 points, name this quantity equal to del-squared, the sum of the second-derivatives of a function in all of its coordinates.
tossups.answer: Laplacian [accept del-squared before mentioned] <Science - Physics>   Chicago Open 2019: What If We Kissed 😳 in the Non-Western Art Distribution 😳  Edited by Chris Ray, Jacob Reed, Alston Boyd, Will Holub-Moorman, Jonathan Magin, and Sriram Pendyala, with contributions by Wonyoung Jang and Michael Kearney.  Packet by the Editors (4)  Bonuses

bonuses.leadin: This formula has both a gamma-to-the-sixth term and a gamma-to-the-fourth term. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: relativistic Liénard-Larmor law [prompt on answers mentioning Liénard but not Larmor]
synchrotron radiation [or magneto·brems·strahlung; do not accept or prompt on just “brehms·strahlung”]
parts: Give this formula that predicts that radiated EM power is proportional to the square of the magnitude of acceleration of component charges.
If acceleration is perpendicular to velocity, the gamma-to-the-sixth term dies and the result is this form of radiation, a relativistic generalization of cyclotron radiation.

Synchrotron radiation is often produced by circulating relativistic electrons in strong magnetic fields. In this effect, those electrons will self-polarize by emitting spin-flip synchrotron radiation, aligning their spins in a direction opposite to the magnetic field.

bonuses.leadin: A house that ruled from this city solidified its power by capturing Lothair III at Chlumec. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: Albert the Bear [or Albrecht der Bär; prompt on partial answer] <History - European>
parts: Identify this largest Bohemian city, home to the Premyslid dynasty.

Lothair’s ally at Chlumec was a Moravian prince with this name, known as “the black.” The battle itself was described in a chronicle by a bishop of Freising with this name, who is best known for writing The Deeds of Emperor Frederick for his nephew, Frederick Barbarossa.
Also captured at Chlumec was this rival of Henry the Proud, who later took part in the Wendish crusade. This member of the House of Ascania became the first Margrave of Brandenburg.

bonuses.leadin: In a 1934 Self-Portrait as a [woman from this place], Amrita Sher-Gil posed herself literally in a man’s shadow, which probably symbolizes her debt to Post-Impressionism. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: Paul Gauguin (Griselda Pollock analyzed Spirit of the Dead Watching.)
parts: Name this place, which is the setting of a painting that Griselda Pollock’s Avant-Garde Gambits analyzes as a response to Manet’s Olympia.
Sher-Gil’s image of Tahiti was largely drawn from the works of this French painter, who infected three preteen Tahitian “wives” with syphilis before his death in 1903.

The background of Sher-Gil’s Self-Portrait imitates paintings from this country. Artworks from this country surround the subjects of both Manet’s portrait of Zola and Van Gogh’s portrait of Père Tanguy.

bonuses.leadin: Reuel Briggs discovers that Western civilization sprang from the ancient Ethiopian kingdom of Telassar in this author’s final novel, Of One Blood. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: the South (The second book is George Fitzhugh’s Sociology for the South.) <Literature - American>
parts: Name this editor of the Colored American Magazine, which serialized her novels Hagar’s Daughter and Contending Forces.
Hopkins was forced to leave the Colored American Magazine after it was secretly purchased by this author of the autobiography Up from Slavery.

Another critic of Washington, Anna Julia Cooper, examined the combined effects of race and gender on black women in a book called A Voice from [this place]. The argument that free trade leads to immorality is central to a mid-nineteenth-century treatise called Sociology for [this place].

bonuses.leadin: Note to Moderator: Hey, you’re doing a great job! Also please do not reveal the prompt in the first answer line, because it is the answer to part two of the bonus. A stone pillar at Jokhang temple commemorates a treaty that one of these figures, Ralpacan, signed with Taizong. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: Dharma Kings [or Chosgyal; prompt on rulers of Tibet or similar answers]
Songsten Gampo [or Songzan Ganbu; prompt on partial answer] <History - Other/World>
parts: Give this term for a group of three rulers, the last of which, Trisong Detsen, invited Guru Rinpoche to establish the Nyingma school of Buddhism in their polity.
The three Dharma kings ruled an empire named for this Himalayan region, which was occupied by China in 1951.

The first of the great Dharma Kings was this man, who formalized the Tibetan alphabet and married Wénchéng, a second cousin of Emperor Tàizōng. He created a group of nine ministers led by the lonchen.

bonuses.leadin: Answer the following about unsupervised machine learning in computer vision, for 10 points each.
answers_sanitized: generative adversarial modeling [or generative adversarial networks; or GANs]
singular value decomposition [or SVD; or principal component analysis or PCA]
parts: First, name this method in computer vision that only requires a set of images from a single class, training one network to produce fake images, and another “discriminator” network to recognize fake from real images. This method has been used to produce photorealistic fake clothing items, interior designs, and so-called “deepfakes.”

Autoencoders are another type of neural network that aim to compress information into low-dimensional latent space encodings. They are a nonlinear generalization of this linear method for doing the same, which factors any matrix into the product of a two square unitary matrices and a diagonal matrix.

Variational autoencoders have a loss term that computes the KL-divergence between the latent space encoding distribution and this distribution. The central limit theorem concerns convergence to this distribution.

bonuses.leadin: This June, the L.A. Philharmonic will be putting on the first production of this composer’s opera Atlas not to be directed by the composer herself. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: Coen Brothers [or Joel and Ethan Coen] (The first film is The Big Lebowski.)
parts: Name this American composer and singer known for her extensive use of experimental vocal techniques in pieces like Dolmen Music.
In a film by this duo, Monk’s “Walking Song” plays while Maude flings paint at a canvas from a harness. This duo helped re-commercialize American bluegrass with their film O Brother, Where Art Thou?
This man featured Monk’s “Road Song” on the soundtrack to his 1986 film True Stories. This man wore a huge, box-like suit as the centerpiece of the 1984 film Stop Making Sense.

bonuses.leadin: This essay begins by distinguishing between “readerly” and “writerly” texts. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this essay, which analyzes a series of textual fragments, or “lexias,” to show that a seemingly realistic narrative represents the collapse of language, money, and gender into the “unbridled circulation of signs.”
This post-structuralist French critic wrote S/Z, as well as Mythologies and “The Death of the Author.”

Post-structuralist critics often use the “semiotic square” introduced in this author’s book Structural Semantics. This theorist, who left his native Lithuania during World War II, also developed the “actantial model,” which breaks down a narrative action into six “actants.”

bonuses.leadin: A 1960 medley by this singer combines “Summertime” with “Sometimes I feel Like a Motherless Child.” For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: Duke Ellington [or Edward Kennedy Ellington] <Arts - Auditory>
parts: Name this singer of “Move On Up a Little Higher,” who performed “How I Got Over” at the March on Washington and sang “Take My Hand, Precious Lord” at Martin Luther King Jr.’s funeral.

Part 2 of “Move On Up a Little Higher” is based on one of these repeating accompaniment patterns. Because of that song’s influence, gospel songs often end with a long improvisation on one of these ostinato grooves.
This bandleader and pianist brought Jackson on for the 1958 studio version of the suite Black, Brown and Beige. This man’s band included composer-performers like Juan Tizol and Billy Strayhorn.

bonuses.leadin: Companies such as Oaktree and Cerberus gained Section 110 SPV status for these financial entities in Ireland, which allowed them to avoid paying taxes. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: Greece [or the Hellenic Republic; or Hellas] <Social Science>
parts: Give this name for funds that intentionally invest in distressed debt in search of high yield, and which have been in the news recently for their role in the debt crises in Argentina and Puerto Rico.

By investing in national bonds, vulture funds bet that the reduction of the amount that will be repaid to creditors—known by this term—will be less than expected. This term more generally refers to the difference between an asset’s market value and the amount that can be used as loan collateral.
In 2012, the vulture fund Dart Management used the threat of a lawsuit against this European nation to force its Antonis Samaras-led government to pay in full on 400 million euro worth of bonds.

bonuses.leadin: Among these people, arrows are planted around a mudyi tree as part of the nkang’a pre-marriage ritual for young girls. For 10 points each:
parts: Name these people whose initiation rites were described in books like The Forest of Symbols.

In his analysis of Ndembu ritual, Victor Turner proposed that rituals form an “anti-structure” out of communitas and this kind of state. In this state, participants temporarily exit their normal social structure.
The Forest of Symbols also includes an essay on mukanda, the Ndembu rite involving this practice. Called khitan in Islam, this ritual is performed in a Jewish brit milah.

bonuses.leadin: This transmembrane protein has alpha and beta chains and associates with CD3. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: MHC [or major histo·compatibility complex; accept human leukocyte antigen or HLA] <Science - Biology>
parts: Name this product of VDJ recombination, specific to a single cell type, whose activation leads to increased ERK signaling, NFAT nuclear translocation, and NF-kappaB activation.

The intracellular TCR CD3 complex has ten ITAM domains, some of which are phosphorylated by this kinase when the extracellular portion of the receptor is activated. Those phosphorylated ITAM domains then bind ZAP-70, which is also phosphorylated by this kinase.

In CD4-positive cells, the T-cell receptor is activated when binding to a complex formed by cognate peptide and the second type of these proteins. The first class of these proteins are present on the surface of all human cells.

bonuses.leadin: Kareem Abdul-Jabbar donated a mansion in this city to a group of Hanafi Muslims led by Hamaas Abdul Khaalis, whose family was brutally murdered here in 1973 after his feud with Elijah Muhammad. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: Washington, D.C. [accept either; accept District of Columbia or the Capital or whatever]
parts: Name this city, whose city council building was seized in a three-day hostage standoff in 1977 by Khaalis’s followers, who also demanded the cancellation of the premier of the film Mohammad, Messenger of God.

This councilman and future DC mayor caught a shotgun blast to the chest during the siege, but escaped through a window and survived. Unfortunately, there was no window in the Vista Hotel Room where he was arrested for smoking crack in a 1990 FBI sting.

Samuel Christian’s Black Mafia also orchestrated the killing of Major Coxon, who funneled illicit funds to the Nation of Islam’s Mosque No. 12 in this city. A compound in this city was owned by the organization MOVE.

bonuses.leadin: An edition of this magazine coined the term “dirty realism” to describe writers like Jayne Ann Phillips and Richard Ford. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this literary magazine that was relaunched in 1979 under editor Bill Buford. Every ten years, starting in 1983, it has published an influential list of the best young British novelists.

Granta’s initial list of “Best of Young British Novelists” included this author, who retold The Iliad from the point of view of Briseis in her 2018 novel The Silence of the Girls. Her trilogy of novels about World War I ends with The Eye in the Door and The Ghost Road.
The third issue of Granta published an excerpt from this Salman Rushdie novel, in which Saleem Sinai is born on the date of India’s independence.

bonuses.leadin: When this theater closed in 1962, its final director Charles Nonon explained “We could never compete with Buchenwald.” For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: Powers of Horror [or Pouvoirs de l’horreur] <Mythology and Other>
parts: Name this Parisian theater known for its naturalistic horror shows, whose name came to signify the genre during the early twentieth century.
This man likened World War I-era London to a horror show with two novels titled Guignol’s Band. This massive anti-Semite also wrote Journey to the End of the Night.

This book by Julia Kristeva claims that Céline’s use of ellipsis in Castle to Castle creates a suspense that “make[s] the Grand Guignol…look like a kindergarten.” This book is primarily an analysis of the “abject.”

bonuses.leadin: According to a book about this philosopher subtitled “Thinking Beyond the Human Condition,” this man privileges the human only in order to open humanity to the rest of nature. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this philosopher, who argued that life takes on two senses, as unitary and as completely differentiated, which must be brought together by recognizing the original creative impulse.

The aforementioned book on Bergson is by this English philosopher, currently at the University of Warwick [WAH-rick]. His work on Bergson and Deleuze includes books like Philosophy and the Adventure of the Virtual.
Ansell-Pearson is perhaps most famous for editing the Blackwell companion to this other philosopher, as well as editing the Cambridge edition of this philosopher’s On the Genealogy of Morality.

bonuses.leadin: A lone brick fireplace in Hampshire, England commemorates soldiers from this country who joined with the Canadian Forestry Corps to help bolster the depleted British timber industry in 1916. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: Portugal [or Portuguese Republic or República Portuguesa]
Autonomous Region of the Azores [or Região Autónoma dos Açores] <History - Mediterranean+>
parts: Name this country whose role in World War II largely turned on its supply of tungsten ore to both sides.

Moisés Bensabat Amzalak, who led the Portuguese Jewish community during World War II, was able to coordinate a number of refugee operations thanks to his friendship with this man, an economist turned dictator who led Portugal’s Estado Novo.

Portugal’s agreement to provide air bases to the Allies staved off a nearly-executed invasion of this location, the subject of War Plan Gray and Operation Alacrity. Battles at Ponta Delgada and Terceira occurred during the Spanish conquest of this location in the Portuguese Succession War.

bonuses.leadin: Answer the following about important institutions in the history of organic chemistry, for 10 points each.
answers_sanitized: Scripps Research [accept The Scripps Research Institute or TSRI]
NMR spectroscopy [or nuclear magnetic resonance spectroscopy or MRS] <Science - Chemistry>
parts: First, name this “birthplace of organic chemistry,” where the regio·selectivity of hydro·halogenation of alkenes was first articulated. Arbuzov also developed his namesake reaction here under Zaitsev.

K. Barry Sharpless, the father of click chemistry and developer of multiple stereoselective oxidation reactions, holds a professorship at this place. Phil Baran, a father of organic synthesis, also holds a professorship here.

Kurt Wüthrich, a Nobel laureate holding a professorship from Scripps, invented this spectroscopic method that can be used to obtain protein structures. It uses radio waves to produce a spectrum with peaks at different values of “chemical shift.”

bonuses.leadin: This island provided the main airbase for international relief flights during the Biafran War. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: Republic of Cameroon [or République de Cameroun]
parts: Identify this island located across the Bight of Bonny from Príncipe. This island hosts the government of Equatorial Guinea in Malabo.
Although part of Equatorial Guinea, Bioko is closer to this other country, whose capital is Yaoundé.

After a failed 2004 coup against Teodoro Obiang, Bioko’s Black Beach Prison became home to Simon Mann, who helped Tim Spicer found this company. Earlier, this company was part of a scandal that brought down the protégé of Michael Somare.

bonuses.leadin: Quintilian’s 12-volume textbook on this activity helped develop its “Five Canons.” For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: oratory [or rhetoric; or public speaking; or persuasion; accept obvious equivalents]
Marcus Tullius Cicero [accept Tully] (The speech is the First Catilinarian.)
parts: Name this activity, whose “Rhodian” style developed as a compromise between its “Attic” and “Asiatic” styles. According to Aristotle, participants in this activity can use ethos, pathos, or logos.
A speech by this orator used prosopopoeia, or personification, to imagine the personified fatherland rebuking an insurgent. In that speech, he asked Jupiter to punish “all the enemies of good men.”

At Rome, this Athenian speechwriter became the model for the “Atticists” because of his lean, plain style. His most famous composition, a defense speech, argues that Euphiletos’s killing of Eratosthenes was justified homicide rather than murder.
